label: thm-mean-field-equation
title: The Mean-Field Equations for the Euclidean Gas
nl_statement: The evolution of the Euclidean Gas in the mean-field limit is governed by a coupled system of equations for the alive density f(t,z) and the dead mass m_d(t), with total population conservation m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1.

equations.label: eq-mean-field-pde-main
equations.latex: \partial_t f = L^\dagger f - c(z)f + B[f, m_d] + S[f]

\partial_t f(t,z) = -
abla\cdot(A(z) f(t,z)) + 
abla\cdot(\mathsf{D}
abla f(t,z)) - c(z)f(t,z) + \lambda_{	ext{revive}} m_d(t)  rac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)} + S[f](t,z)

hypotheses.text: Initial conditions: f(0, ·) = f_0 and m_d(0) = 1 - ∫_Ω f_0, with m_a(0) + m_d(0) = 1.
c(z) is zero in the interior and positive near the boundary.
λ_revive > 0 is the revival rate (free parameter, typical values 0.1-5).

conclusion.text: The coupled system conserves total population: m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1 for all t.

implicit_assumptions.text: Domain Ω is a bounded Euclidean domain with reflecting boundaries.
Operators L†, B, S are well-defined and preserve non-negativity.

label: thm-mass-conservation
title: Total Mass Conservation and Population Dynamics
nl_statement: Any sufficiently regular solution to the Mean-Field Equations conserves the total population mass over time and satisfies the specified dynamics for the alive population mass, balancing revival from the dead population and killing.

equations.latex: m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1 \quad \text{(for all } t > 0 \text{ if holds initially)}

hypotheses.text: Any sufficiently regular solution $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ to the Mean-Field Equations

conclusion.text: The total population mass $m_a(t) + m_d(t)$ is conserved for all $t > 0$, implying $m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1$ if initial, and the alive mass evolves as $\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}m_a(t) = \lambda_{\text{rev}} m_d(t) - k_{\text{killed}}[f](t)$

The killing functional k_killed[f] is well-defined for regular f

label: thm-killing-rate-consistency
title: Consistency of the Interior Killing Rate Approximation
nl_statement: Under regularity assumptions on the domain, integrator, and density, there exists a smooth compactly supported killing rate function c such that the discrete exit probability converges pointwise to c as the timestep τ approaches 0, and the expected discrete killing fraction converges to the continuous killing integral with an explicit error bound involving √τ and the L¹ norm of the density difference.

hypotheses.text: Regularity assumptions on the density for killing (assumption-density-regularity-killing)

conclusion.text: There exists a smooth killing rate c ∈ C^∞_c(Ω) with compact support in T_δ such that: (i) pointwise convergence of (1/τ) p_exit to c(x,v), with c explicitly given; (ii) uniform convergence of (1/τ) K_discrete(τ) to K_continuous, with error bound C(√τ + ||f^τ - f||_{L^1}).

constraints: c(x,v) = ((v · n_x(x))⁺ / d(x)) · 1_{d(x)<δ} if x ∈ T_δ, else 0

label: thm-mean-field-limit-informal
title: Mean-Field Limit (Informal Statement)
nl_statement: In the joint limit as the number of particles N approaches infinity and the timestep τ approaches 0 with τ scaling as O(N^{-α}) for α > 0, the empirical density of the N-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics converges weakly to the mean-field density f.

equations.latex: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))

hypotheses.text: The system consists of N-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics (X_i^τ(t), V_i^τ(t))_{i=1}^N with timestep τ.
The empirical density is defined as f_N^τ(t, x, v) = (1/N) ∑_{i=1}^N δ(x - X_i^τ(t), v - V_i^τ(t)).
hypotheses.latex: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))

hypotheses.text: Joint limit N → ∞, τ → 0 with τ = O(N^{-α}) for α > 0.

conclusion.text: The empirical density converges weakly to the mean-field density f.

variables.description: Number of particles in the Fragile Gas system

variables.description: Discrete timestep in the dynamics

variables.name: scaling exponent
variables.description: Positive exponent in the τ scaling

variables.name: empirical density
variables.description: Empirical measure of particle positions and velocities

variables.name: mean-field density
variables.description: Limiting density in the mean-field regime

variables.name: particle position

variables.description: Velocity of the i-th particle at time t

implicit_assumptions.text: The N-particle dynamics are well-defined and stable under the discrete timestep τ.
The mean-field density f satisfies the corresponding mean-field kinetic equation.
Weak convergence holds in the space of probability measures on position-velocity space.

steps.text: Relies on killing rate consistency theorem (thm-killing-rate-consistency), standard kinetic theory for transport operator from kinetic generator (def-kinetic-generator), and Law of Large Numbers for cloning operators (Section 2.3).
